title: Â¿Monjas cismÃ¡ticas? - La Nueva EspaÃ±a
text: Califican de cisma la ruptura de las monjas clarisas de Belorado con la Iglesia catÃ³lica. Para ser cismÃ¡tico se necesita ser mÃ¡s inteligente. Es necesario un argumentario doctrinal consistente y no estulticias con intereses crematÃ­sticos. El manifiesto que han sacado en Instagram las infelices monjas, llamando herejes a los Ãºltimos seis papas, es estrambÃ³tico y ridÃ­culo. Siento que la iglesia espaÃ±ola sea por esta necedad primera noticia de los informativos, provocando hilaridad. Abandonar la Iglesia para guarecerse en el paraguas de un Â¿iluminado? que basta verle hablar, andar y vestir para emitir un juicio acertado sobre su personalidad. No deja de ser un caso insÃ³lito. En EspaÃ±a hay actualmente mÃ¡s de 700 monasterios habitados por 7.500 religiosas que tienen como norma de vida el \"ora et labora\" de San Benito. El monacato comienza en el siglo IV y han sido grandes custodios y promotores de la cultura, del arte, de la farmacia, de la agricultura... No es extraÃ±o que posean, fruto del trabajo de tantas generaciones, un gran patrimonio que, aunque sea de la iglesia, se tiene conciencia de que pertenece a la humanidad. Con el \"ora\" se inspiraban y con el \"labora\" lo realizaban. En ellos se practicÃ³ siempre la hospitalidad. En ese ambiente conventual cultivaron su espÃ­ritu y personalidad histÃ³ricas mujeres como Santa Teresa de JesÃºs, la sevillana Sor Ãngela de la Cruz... SerÃ­a interminable la lista de las que fueron grandes mujeres monjas y de la labor humana y cultural que realizaron. La situaciÃ³n actual es preocupante. Por la secularizaciÃ³n creciente y la pÃ©rdida de horizontes trascendentes, se van cerrando muchos de estos monasterios. Surge la esperanza con comunidades nuevas como la de Iesu Communio en Lerma y Valencia, fundada por Sor VerÃ³nica, curiosamente connovicia de la abadesa \"separada\". La vida monÃ¡stica tiene muchos siglos de historia como para atreverse a predecir su final. Estamos en tiempos que los sociÃ³logos de la religiÃ³n llaman \"eclipse de Dios\". Vivimos un realce materialista en el que las ciencias, con sus prodigiosos logros, nos pueden ofuscar cerrando el paso a la trascendencia. Los monasterios son un oasis. En ellos se oye y se siente otra voz que abre a la plegaria y a la alabanza y acerca a la plenitud de sentido de ser humano. Este domingo de la fiesta de la SantÃ­sima Trinidad reclaman nuestra atenciÃ³n para admiremos el Misterio de Dios en el que \"nos movemos y existimos\". Esa es experiencia. El caso de Belorado es demasiado estrafalario como para que logre tanto espacio mediÃ¡tico. Lo sagrado estÃ¡ a veces muy cerca de lo ridÃ­culo. Y de los interesen econÃ³micos. Todo parece que esta es la causa. A la vista estÃ¡ en la vida que se permite y los atuendos que adornan al falso obispo-personaje. Una cosa es clara: en el capÃ­tulo actual de \"la mujer en la Iglesia\", las monjas de clausura merecen una atenciÃ³n y consideraciÃ³n especial.

title: Errani e Vavassori campioni agli US Open nel doppio misto: trionfo storico!
text:
Errani e Vavassori campioni agli US Open nel doppio misto: trionfo storico! Il tandem azzurro scrive una nuova pagina dell'Italtennis grazie al successo in finale sulla coppia Usa Townsend-Young 05.09 .2024 ( Aggiornata il 05.09.2024 23:23 ) 2 min
Errani vavassori Us Open
Trionfo azzurro allo Us Open ! Sara Errani e Andrea Vavassori si aggiudicano la finale del doppio misto, superando in 1 ora e 28 minuti di gioco la coppia statunitense formata dalla campionessa carica nel doppio femminile a Wimbledon Taylor Townsend e dal n.1350 Atp Donald Young , al suo ultimo torneo in carriera. Al Flushing meadows di New York, il tandem tricolore si impone con il finale di 7(7)-6(0), 7-5.
Errani-Vavassori: Ã¨ il primo titolo in uno Slam Il successo rimediato sul campo dell'Arthur Ashe, vale dunque il primo titolo conquistato da un tandem italiano in uno Slam. In semifinale infatti, Errani e Vavassori avevano scritto una nuova pagina dell'Italtennis, portando per la prima volta una coppia azzurra in finale di un torneo del Grande Slam, grazie al successo sugli altri statunitensi in gara Tyra Grant e Aleksandar Kovacevic (6-3, 7-5).
Errani: "Anno incredibile" Queste le parole di Sara Errani al termine dell'incontro: "Ãˆ un momento speciale per me. Poterlo condividere con Andrea Ã¨ bellissimo. Quest'anno Ã¨ stato incredibile" . Gli ha fatto eco il compagno Vavassori: "Ãˆ un sogno diventato realtÃ  per me e ci sono riuscito con Sara, che Ã¨ una giocatrice e una donna straordinaria" .
Gli Azzurri che hanno fatto la storia Solo 3 tennisti italiani avevano conquistato la finale nei misti dei Major. Prima di Errani e Vavassori infatti, si rimanda a Nicola Pietrangeli e alla britannica Shirley Bloomer nel 1958, e a Raffaella Reggi e lo spagnolo Sergio Casal agli Us Open del 1986. Tandem azzurri per metÃ  dunque, a loro volta preceduti dalla prima finale di sempre raggiunta da Uberto De Morpurgo e la statunitense Elizabeth Ryan , poi sconfitti dai francesi Suzanne Lenglen e Jean Borotra .

author: David Looby
title: Glass falls onto main street of Co Wexford town on busy Christmas shopping day
text:
Glass falls onto main street of Co Wexford town on busy Christmas shopping day
Second â€˜dangerousâ€™ incident in a month on busy street prompts call for action from councillor
A review of New Ross townâ€™s old buildings has been suggested after a pane of glass fell onto a footpath on South Street on one of the busy shopping days leading up to Christmas.
Glass fell from an upstairs window at Doranâ€™s jewellers on Thursday morning â€“ a day which saw strong gusts of winds hit the town and area.
It follows on from mortar falling from the side of a four storey premises on the same street just before lunch on Black Friday, November 24. On that occasion part of South Street was closed to traffic for a short time and a follow up structural check on the building was carried out by council staff.
New Ross Municipal District manager Alan Fitzhenry confirmed that the footpath in front of Doranâ€™s was closed to pedestrians for a time on Thursday morning as the glass was cleared and the property made safe.
â€œNobody was hurt, thankfully,â€ he said. â€œWe closed the footpath for about 30 minutes to facilitate making the premises safe.â€ Cllr Michael Sheehan praised the council crew who acted quickly, closing the path.
"They got the glass cleared and windows boarded up. Mercifully nobody was around. It was daytime. The district manager got a phone call and a complaint that glass had fallen onto the street. That could have been very dangerous.
"Itâ€™s an old building and the windows would be really old. A structural review might be needed for the townâ€™s older buildings.â€ He said a new system is needed whereby anyone who owns an empty retail premises doesnâ€™t get their commercial rates paid back to them.
"If there is a vacant shop downtown and your rates bill is â‚¬2,000 and itâ€™s empty you can get up to 90pc back. I think weâ€™re going to have to stop that and the philosophy should be use it or lose it. Doranâ€™s has been sold and a new owner has plans for it, so thatâ€™s welcome news.â€

author: Matthew Wilson
title: Travelers Reveal The 6 Biggest Hidden Gems In Europe To Visit (And Two Popular Places To Avoid)
text:
Are finalling pulling the trigger on that trip to Europe you've always dreamed of? Then boy, do I have some recommendations for you. Sure, the Effel Tower looks good on a postcard. And who doesn't want to imagine themselves royalty in London? But consider going off the beaten path this year.
As Robert Frost once said, it makes all the difference. Or something like that. Travelers recently took to Reddit to share their own stories of adventure, and from that you can find some hidden gems. After all Europe is a big place, why not give some of these other places a chance? You'll be sure to make some memories of your own.
Hidden Gems Of Europe
French Basque Country, France
Forget Paris, head to French Basque Country instead. One traveler described it as the perfect place to take a scenic drive.
They wrote, "San SebastiÃ¡n is a nice town that you hear a lot about, but French Basque Country is also really nice. It's a 30-minute drive from San SebastiÃ¡n all along the Atlantic coast, and no passport is needed to visit. Saint-Jean-de-Luz and Biarritz are two beautiful towns, and Bayonne is worth a visit for great Basque food. The countryside is amazing, with quaint villages and rolling hills. This part of the country goes to show that there is way more to visit in France than just Paris."
Madeira, Portugal
If you love a place with a lot of scenery then Madiera, Portugal should be on your destinations list.
One traveler wrote, "Madeira, Portugal. I'd always assumed this was a destination for old folks, and I only went a few years ago because there were ridiculously cheap flights from Scotland. I had the best 10 days ever. I loved walking around the huge variety of stunning landscapes: along the coast, hillsides, and deep valleys, and paths that seemed to go in and above the clouds. What a stunning island."
Tallinn, Estonia
Now, we're really getting off the beaten path in our Europe vacation.
"Tallinn, Estonia. I really wasn't expecting much when I visited. In fact, I mostly just went because I was traveling from Helsinki to London and it was an off-the-beaten-path destination for a quick day trip. But wow, Tallinn was beautiful, and the people were so friendly! I'd go back for a proper vacation in a heartbeat," as one traveler describes.
Krakow, Poland
You may be able to pick Warsaw on a map, but if you want to visit a historic part of Europe then consider Krakow. One traveler wrote, "Krakow, Poland, is a stunning city that is often overlooked. Unlike Warsaw, Krakow wasn't devastated by World War II, and the Soviets didn't rebuild anything, so it still boasts its old city architecture. It's genuinely so beautiful, and I'd highly recommend seeing the city center at night."
Iceland
Technically not part of the continent of Europe, but Iceland should totally be on your list to visit. It's honestly underrated. One wrote, "Iceland. Despite its growing popularity and tourism, I still think it's underrated. The nature there is just plain unparalleled by anywhere else I've been in the world. I've visited twice, and I'm already looking to go back a third time."
Slovenia
Not to be confused with Slovakia, Slovenia is a an excellent place to visit if you love the outdoors.
One adventurer wrote, "Slovenia. I went on the recommendation of an old roommate and was blown away. The country is full of absolutely stunning scenery. It's an excellent holiday destination if you like the outdoors or road-tripping. I will absolutely go back at some point."
Places To Avoid
Consider passing on Venice, Italy as it's not quite worth the hype. One traveler found out the hard way. They wrote, "Venice. I know that sounds like blasphemy to some people. But I found it stinky, dirty, and unnecessarily expensive. I was bored within six hours, and I had three days to fill. I ended up traveling out of the city and exploring the lovely surrounding cities and countryside instead of spending my time in Venice."
Meanwhile, Geneva, Switzerland is gorgeous but pricey. It will probably break your pocket book.
One wrote, "Geneva. While it was a pretty city, the soul-crushing cost of everything definitely weighed down my experience there. I never expected to pay 24 francs for a hamburger in my life."
